queries.description: The order of evaluation for the '#' and '##' operators may differ between compilers, which can cause unexpected behaviour if more than one '#' or '##' operator is used.
queries.name: A macro parameter immediately following a # operator shall not immediately be followed by a ##

implementation_scope.description: This query applies to function like macros and not object like macros. This rule strictly disallows the use of # operator followed by a ## and other combinations are permitted.

RULE-20-11.title: A macro parameter immediately following a # operator shall not immediately be followed by a ## operator

queries.description: A macro parameter used in different contexts such as: 1) an operand to the # or ## operators where it is not expanded, versus 2) elsewhere where it is expanded, makes code more difficult to understand.
queries.name: A macro parameter used as an operand to the # or ## operators shall only be used as an operand to these operators

RULE-20-12.title: A macro parameter used as an operand to the # or ## operators, which is itself subject to further macro replacement, shall only be used as an operand to these operators

queries.description: Using the #undef preprocessor directive makes code more difficult to understand.
queries.name: #undef should not be used

queries.description: Using anything other than a standard include guard form can make code confusing and can lead to multiple or conflicting definitions.
queries.name: Precautions shall be taken in order to prevent the contents of a header file being included more than once

implementation_scope.description: This query defines header file as any file that is included regardless of file extension. This query does not consider the use of `#pragma once` as a permitted header guard.

DIR-4-10.title: Precautions shall be taken in order to prevent the contents of a header file being included more than once
